title.narrative: West Africa Ebola Crisis Appeal

description.narrative: Over 11,000 people died and over 28,000 were infected by the Ebola virus. The outbreak was not only a health crisis, but also a humanitarian crisis with global dimensions. DEC member agencies and their partners worked urgently to help stop the spread of the disease and providing support to those affected by the crisis. Donations from the UK public for the appeal raised £37 million and have helped hundreds of thousands of people. DEC fundraising for this appeal is now closed but the money raised will continue to be spent over a two year period ending in October 2016.

mailing-address.narrative: Ground Floor, 43 Chalton Street, London NW1 1DU, UK.

title.narrative: Ebola Crisis Appeal Response Review
Supporting Primary School Girls and Children with Disabilities in the context of the Government’s Ebola Transition and Recovery Plan

description.narrative: This programme provides targeted support to up to 7,477 girls and children with disabilities in six operational districts – Bo, Kenema, Kailahun, Tonkolili, and Kambia - helping them return to and remain in formal education after school closures caused by the Ebola crisis disrupted their access to education. The project engages with these children directly, through bursaries and study-groups; with their schools, through support to protection, psycho-social services, and accelerated learning core content roll-out; with their communities through social mobilization; and with the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology for more inclusive schools and improved access to education.

Maintaining a Resilient Zero in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Implemented by a consortium of partners, this project works to improve Sierra Leone's capability for early detection and response to Ebola virus disease (EVD) and other public health emergencies. Working with District Health Management teams (DHMTs) and other partners to strengthen Sierra Leone's Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response System (IDSR), consortium partners provide technical and operational support to enable prompt and effective detection and response to communicable disease outbreaks, including EVD.

Lesson Plans and Training of Teachers (SSEIP)

description.narrative: This project is part of the UK Department for International Development's support to the President's 10-24 month Post-Ebola Recovery Priorities in Education, provided through the new Secondary Education Improvement Programme (SSEIP), the goal of which is to improve the learning outcomes of more than 1.4 million boys and girls in Sierra Leone by 2020. Implemented by an IRC-led consortium of partners, the project's objective is to contribute towards the improvement of learning conditions in the country by developing simple-to-use and high quality lesson plans for Language Arts/English and Mathematics teachers across all grade levels, and training teachers on the use of the lesson plans.

title.narrative: IRC Annual Report 2015
IRC UK Annual Report 2016
Impact of Community Engagement on Infection Prevention and Control Measures for Ebola Preparedness in Western Uganda

description.narrative: The IRC will design and implement a community engagement intervention, including activities such as regular communication with communities, establishment of community-based focal points, partnering with local community-based organisations, and formation of community feedback mechanisms. The primary outcome of this research is improved Infection Prevention and Control Measures (IPC) in health facilities in western Uganda, through building accountability and strengthening relationships between health facilities and local communities. This will be demonstrated by improved measurable IPC scores in facilities during preparedness, changes in behavior and perceptions / awareness of Ebola virus disease and increase in Ebola preparedness activities (such as creation of isolation areas at health facilities) in the targeted health facility catchment areas.

title.narrative: Freetown WASH Consortium: Improving WASH Services in Western Area Urban and Western Area Rural Districts in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: The proposed FWC WASH programme seeks to meaningfully contribute to the realization of GoSL’s Post-Ebola Recovery Programme. Of the six priority sectors identified under recovery programme, FWC will mainly contribute to Key Result Areas (KRA) in the water and health sectors. In relation to the water sector, the new FWC programme will contribute to KRA ‘Providing a sustainable short and long term solutions to Freetown water supply’. In health sector, the FWC programme is aligned to KRA of saving lives of children and mothers and preventing, detecting and responding to epidemics through its solid and liquid waste management and behaviour change communication (BCC) and community engagement and disaster risk reduction (DRR) components. Most importantly FWC as a member of the water and sanitation working group member of President Delivery Team has made significant contribution in developing pro-poor WASH interventions for GoSL’s 24 month recovery plan for water and sanitation sector plans.

sector.code: EMERGENCY RESPONSE – WATER, SANITATION AND HYGIENE

title.narrative: Band Aid Recovery and Reintegration of Ebola Survivors and EDV affected Communities CIFD SL

description.narrative: Expected Outcomes Total project of 6 partners 3,060 survivors and other vulnerable people severely affected by the Ebola virus will have the ability to support themselves with vital access to food, without which they cannot survive. The project will also have a knock on effect on thousands of other people by bringing down the price of food and making it more widely available to others in the community. Many Ebola survivors have been left with nothing, their homes and belongings having been destroyed in the decontamination process, and therefore this project will also help restore their dignity and hope for the future, which is of crucial importance as the stigma suffered by Ebola survivors remains rife. This project will enable the families to move forward and build a new life, free of Ebola.

The project will provide support to approximately 3,360 people with access to seeds and tools in order to enable them to grow food and ensure the long term survival of their families. This will be achieved through the provision of seeds and livestock to 510 Ebola survivors in rural communities; The seeds provided will be rice, cassava, potatoes, groundnuts and green vegetables. In addition the project will provide male and female goats as well as hens and cockerels, to provide families will vital sources of eggs and milk. The beneficiaries will be able to quickly harvest their food by August this year, and this will mean that they have a sustainable source of food and income for many months to come, whist also meeting their basic needs for food in the coming weeks.

title.narrative: Prevention of Health Epidemics in Kaialhu Kono and Pujehun District

description.narrative: oThe target population will be equipped with the requisite information and knowledge to protect and prevent themselves against infectious diseases. oAn estimated 80% of the adult target population will have sufficient knowledge in the prevention of Ebola, Lassa fever, and cholera; and will be in a position to inform the responsible local authorities in the case of corresponding danger. oTarget population have alternative sources of protein and have their hygiene and sanitation improved to contribute to their improved health status

•Establish information, control and response mechanisms to prevent transmission of infectious diseases such as Ebola, Lassa Fever and Cholera, • Initiate early response by local authorities • Organize awareness campaigns towards disease prevention, • Develop early warning systems to timely curb the early spread of contagious infectious diseases through simulations. •Conduct PVCA in 9 PHUs and their catchment villages in Kono and Kaialhun Support the development of action plans in Kono and Kailahun district Support the implementation of action plans in 22 communities

title.narrative: Scottish Ebola riposte Lubero DRC

description.narrative: By the end of the project implementation period, people living in the affected areas will benefit from project's outcomes to accept and collaborate with the reposte team and minimize the resistance. wash facilities infrastructures will be improved to offer appropriate and fair hygienic environment to prevent form Ebola risk contamination. People in the communities will be enable with communication skills and wash technic around EVD to increase their resilience.

This project aim to reduce the risk of Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) contamination in South Lubero, North Kivu, DRC through community engagement and WASH. Affected communities are mobilized to consult and collaborate with Ebola response teams and reduce resistance. Improved Wash infrastructure, access to hygiene materials and hygiene promotion lead to good and consistently applied Wash practices and help prevent human to human transmission of EVD

title.narrative: Food and Non- Food Items to Quarantined Homes in Kailhun

description.narrative: Contribute to the containment, disruption and eradication of Ebola in Sierra Leone

The purpose is to reduce the suffering that victims in the worst hit Ebola communities are experiencing and below are the main activities: i) Provide food and NFIs to 80 households (approximately 480 individuals) in Kailahun district. Kailahun is identified as the most vulnerable and isolatedand was first hit by the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone. ii) Promote behaviour change through radio networks by messaging on the identified gaps in knowledge and behaviour. This will reach approximately 1,000,000 people in the project location. . The radio messaging will focus on radio discussions where panelists will include Ebola survivors, religious leaders, traditional leaders and activists. Topics of discussion will include modes of transmission of Ebola, the role of physical contact and traditional rites in spreading the disease. News broadcasts, which will include interviews with partners, beneficiaries, local government officials, survivors and local leaders will be another important means of dissemination information on the project. iii) Provide personal protective equipment and essential medial supplies to CA partners to reduce the risk.

title.narrative: Band Aid Recovery and Reintegration of Ebola Survivors and EVD Affected Vulnerable Communities CAWEC

description.narrative: Expected Outcomes Total project of 6 partners 3,060 survivors and other vulnerable people severely affected by the Ebola virus will have the ability to support themselves with vital access to food, without which they cannot survive. The project will also have a knock on effect on thousands of other people by bringing down the price of food and making it more widely available to others in the community. Many Ebola survivors have been left with nothing, their homes and belongings having been destroyed in the decontamination process, and therefore this project will also help restore their dignity and hope for the future, which is of crucial importance as the stigma suffered by Ebola survivors remains rife. This project will enable the families to move forward and build a new life, free of Ebola.

The seeds provided will be rice, cassava, potatoes, groundnuts and green vegetables. In addition the project will provide male and female goats as well as hens and cockerels, to provide families will vital sources of eggs and milk. The beneficiaries will be able to quickly harvest their food by August this year, and this will mean that they have a sustainable source of food and income for many months to come, whist also meeting their basic needs for food in the coming weeks.

title.narrative: Food and non food items to quarantined homes in Western Area

description.narrative: Contribute to the containment, disruption and eradication of Ebola in Sierra Leone

The purpose is to reduce the suffering that victims in the worst hit Ebola communities are experiencing and below are the main activities:
The main activities of the intervention are as follows: i) Provide food and non-food items to 270 households (approximately 1980 individuals) in the Western Area (both rural and urban). The Western Area has become the new epicentre with 664 confirmed Ebola cases as at 13th October 2014. ii) Promote behaviour change through radio networks by messaging on the identified gaps in knowledge and behaviour. This will reach approximately 1,000,000 people in the project location. . The radio messaging will focus on radio discussions where panelists will include Ebola survivors, religious leaders, traditional leaders and activists. Topics of discussion will include modes of transmission of Ebola, the role of physical contact and traditional rites in spreading the disease. News broadcasts, which will include interviews with partners, beneficiaries, local government officials, survivors and local leaders will be another important means of dissemination information on the project. iii) Provide personal protective equipment and essential medial supplies to CA partners to reduce the risk.

title.narrative: DEC 2 Recovery and Reintegration of Ebola Survivors and EVD Affected Vulnerable Communities YPPD

description.narrative: Children and Youths (ebola survivors) have enhance social and vocational skills to strengthen reintegration in to communities. Food production capacity of subsistence/small farmers (Ebola survivors, families who have lost breadwinners, Ebola widows and others identified as vulnerable) is strengthened through the provision of seeds, farm animals, tools and training,

Training in basic Agronomic practices Training in basic Animal husbandry practices Sports & Games activities-3 activities per district 22 Unemployed Youths giving Institutional training Rehabilitation of 3 PHUs in Bombali District Provide furniture, including mattresses for PHUs Support social mobilization and community health promotion activities: conduct re-orientation training for former TBAs as SRH and MCH promoters; organize community meetings for local communities and authorities, conduct bi- weekly community radio programmes, reproduce various IEC materials and disseminate public health messages; identify and train Community Health Volunteers to raise awareness on the risk of communicable and other preventable diseases; establish and train rural integrated health community theatres. Improve supply chain and logistics in the health system through support to the District Health Management Teams (DHMTs) to deliver basic wooden furniture to PHUs: table, cupboards, chairs, and benches), delivery beds and wooden medical/admission beds to under resourced PHUs Support DHMTs to conduct routine supervision, monitoring & out-reach visits to PHUs within the targeted chiefdom/district with registered/licensed motor bikes, etc

title.narrative: Report on progress following mid-term review
website
Mobilising Young Slum Dwellers in Liberia to Rebuild Communities after the Ebola outbreak

description.narrative: Output 1: Communities have increased access to health and hygiene services and information Output 2: Young slum dwellers have the skills, knowledge and resources to increase their economic resilience Output 3: Young slum dwellers and slum communities have increased knowledge and skills to build disaster resilience Output 4: Young slum dwellers are supported to participate in community decision-making processes and demand their socio-economic rights

Project intended impact: This project will contribute to the social and economic empowerment of 710 young slum dwellers (15-24) in six zones of West Point, Monrovia. Young women and men will receive supports and trainings in livelihoods, Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR), advocacy and health and hygiene which will empower them to become leaders within their communities, provide support to 12,960 other slum dwellers and act as catalysts for long term community change and development.

title.narrative: DEC 2014 Ebola Crisis Appeal: Responding to the Ebola outbreak Phase 2

description.narrative: Increasing awareness of older people’s needs and priorities among key stakeholders engaged in the post-Ebola response. Strengthening the capacity of state and non-state actors engaged in post-Ebola recovery activities to develop and implement age-friendly services. Ensuring 1,200 older people have increased livelihoods opportunities.

The 2014 Ebola outbreak resulted in over 10,000 deaths in West Africa. During the epidemic, Age International worked with Restless Development to ensure older people were included in the response and healthcare workers were trained on older people’s specific needs. Following our needs assessment in 2015, we seconded an Inclusion Advisor to Sierra Leone, and are working with Restless Development to help older people recover their livelihoods.

title.narrative: Emergency Ebola( EVD) virus Response in Equateur and North Kivu

description.narrative: Coordination efforts are ongoing on the ground and Oxfam is one of the agencies on the ground with ongoing Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WaSH) in schools programs. This places Oxfam at an advantage of presence and awareness of actors on the ground as well as gaps. Oxfam works with communities through Community Health Volunteers (CHVs) and having implemented in the area, it will be easy to reactivate and train CHVs for this particular response. This will be a priority as CHVs play a key role in community mobilisation as well as setting up of community structures eg community health committees. Once this activity is attained Oxfam together with the CHVs will then commence an intense community mobilisation - awareness raising campaign and at the same time undertake identify most vulnerable households to support with Non -Food Item (NFI) kits. It is expected that by the end of 45 days Oxfam's work will have covered a safe water chain , hand washing and distribute hygiene kits for the beneficiary communities.

title.narrative: Advancing Post-Ebola Water, Sanitation,and Hygiene (WASH) for Children and Women

description.narrative: Almost 3,000 Liberians, including 1,800 children under 5, die each year from diarrhea – nearly 90% of which is directly related to poor water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). Poor sanitation is a contributing factor, through its impact on malnutrition, to other leading causes of child mortality. This project will expand access to safe, quality WASH facilities, prioritizing children's health. Oxfam will harness local momentum generated during its Ebola response around improving sanitation and hygiene practices, building local infrastructure, and information sharing about disease prevention, setting Liberian children and communities on the path toward improved child health and resilience.

title.narrative: Ebola prevention in Musanze Burera Nyabihu and Rubavu Districts of Rwanda

description.narrative: The objective of the proposed project is to contribute to the Government of Rwanda efforts to meeting the requirement of the National Contingency Plan for Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) to ensure communities are well prepared to save their lives. The proposed project will focus on aspects of water, sanitation and hygiene promotion (WASH) during the anticipation period and target vulnerable population groups in identified priority districts of Rubavu and Musanze. Safe drinking water, clean sanitation facilities, and good hygiene practice are essential for Ebola patient treatment and preventing the transmission of Ebola (and other infectious diseases) in health care facilities, treatment centres, households, and communities. Long -term, sustainable public health and WASH infrastructure and education are key to prepare communities, particularly in Rwanda, and prevent future outbreaks of Ebola and other diseases. In this framework, the proposed project plans to target two main population groups who have already been identified in the National EVD Contingency plan as people at risk of contamination or spreading the disease. These are the traders who are moving between the two countries as well as community health workers committees (HWCs) at the sector level. Main project activities will include: - Setting up portable hand washing stations (Kandagira dukarabe in local language) at specific public areas (border stations, at the two Ebola Treatment Centres (ETCs) in Rubavu and Musanze, and at key and selected locations to be agreed upon with the HWCs at sectors in Rubavu and Musanze ); - Provision of training to HWCs at sector level, to Oxfam and local Non -Governmental Organisation (NGO) staff on critical WASH actions in preventing an EVD outb

title.narrative: Emergency Response to Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: • To increase public awareness of EVD in order to reduce the factors for its transmission in Freetown and Koinadugu. • To support MoHS and the District Health Management Teams (DHMT) with sensitisation, early case detection and referral system, as well as with material for infection control (e.g. gloves, aprons, rubber boots, face masks). • To support MoW at district level with the national Ebola response plan in the identified gaps focused in WASH related activities, facilities and consumables like chlorine at community level as well as for the isolation centres in Freetown, Lakka and Kerry Town and temporary holding centre Koinadugu.

title.narrative: Emergency Response Ebola Outbreak - Port Loko, Northern Province, Sierra Leone

description.narrative: To increase public awareness of Ebola Virus Disease in order to reduce the factors for its transmission in Port Loko. To support MoHS and District Health Management Teams (DHMT) with sensitisation, early case detection and referral system as well as with material for infection control (eg. gloves, aprons, rubber boots, face masks). To support MoW at district level with national Ebola response plan in the identified gaps focused in WASH related activities, facilities and consumables like chlorine at community level as well as for the isolation centres in Port Loko.

title.narrative: Strengthening Food Security and Sustainable Livelihoods Project in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: This project will work towards improving food security and supporting livelihood recovery for extremely poor households affected by Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) in Koinadugu, Port Loko and Western Rural areas, by responding to emerging needs in food security, livelihoods, protection and gender justice. Addressing technical needs in crop production through increase agricultural extension services, provision of quality inputs for production to farmers and supporting post harvest management.. Capacity building of women organisation and supporting women groups to improve and diversify livelihood option to increase income. Pilot community social safety net programme of food loan and advocate for a national wide social safety net programme that support the most vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Post Ebola Women's Economic Empowerment Initiative

description.narrative: In the frame of post Ebola global efforts to support communities affected by the disease in Liberia and Sierra Leone, UN Women and Oxfam are planning – in support to the efforts of the Governments of Liberia and Sierra Leone - the development of a large scale women's economic empowerment programme in both countries that targets 200,000 direct and 1,000,000 indirect beneficiaries. This ambitious programme, resulting from discussions between the CEOs of both organisations, H.E The President of Liberia and H.E The President of Sierra Leone, seek to raise over $50 million over the next 5 years to invest in the economic recovery and empowerment of women whose livelihoods have been adversely affected by the Ebola crisis. The aim is to directly support the recovery of 100,000 women in each country and through them impact positively the lives of more than 1 million people. We'll recruit a consultant, in order to support the development of this programme. He will assist in data and information collection that will feed into the design of the programme. The below sections outline what is expected of the consultant.

title.narrative: West Africa Ebola 2014

description.narrative: In March 2014, a rapidly evolving outbreak of Ebola haemorrhagic fever started in forested areas of south eastern Guinea. As of 25 March 2014, 86 suspected cases including 60 deaths had been reported in Gueckedou, Macenta and Kissidougou districts including four health care workers. Thirteen cases tested positive for Ebola virus, confirming the first Ebola haemorrhagic fever outbreak in Guinea. The epicentre of Gueckedou borders Liberia and Sierra Leone, where there are usually high numbers of people crossing open borders into these neighbouring countries. In March 2014, Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) cases were confirmed in Liberia, and then in May 2014 in Sierra Leone. EVD cases were confirmed in urban and rural areas of these three countries of intense transmission. Smaller numbers of EVD cases were confirmed in Mali, Nigeria and Senegal in August and September 2014 but these countries have all since been declared Ebola free by the World Health Organisation (WHO). Liberia was declared Ebola free in May 2015 but there were further cases in July 2015. In total there have been approximately 28,331 confirmed/probable cases and approximately 11,310 deaths worldwide â€“ with the majority of these cases being in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea. Approximately 881 healthcare workers have contracted Ebola and 513 healthcare workers have died (information as of 23Â September 2015).

title.narrative: DRC Ebola outbreak 2018

description.narrative: 9th Ebola epidemic outbreak in DRC in the Equateur region. BikoroÂ and Mbandaka city affected, this is the hub for regional exchanges, in proximity to CAR and Republic of Congo. A week after this was declared over, DRC were confronted with aÂ 10th outbreak in North Kivu Province. On 1 August 2018, the Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of the Congo notified WHO of a new outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD) in North Kivu Province, in the eastern part of the country. The province of North Kivu is among the most populated provinces, with eight million inhabitants. It shares borders with four other provinces (Ituri, South Kivu, Maniema and Tshopo) as well as with Uganda and Rwanda. (There is a tangible risk of EVD transmission in Uganda and Rwanda).Â The sub-region has been experiencing intense insecurity and worsening humanitarian crisis, with over one million internally displaced people and a continuous efflux of refugees to the neighbouring countries, including Uganda, Burundi and Tanzania. The protracted conflict context makes the emergency response activities more difficult because of restrained access and security risks. The EVD outbreak is rapidly evolving, with more new confirmed cases and deaths occurring. WHO regional risk raised to HIGH. Category of emergency (IFRC): RED Â Â RC launched a One International Appeal in May '18 fundraising for all RC components involved in the response (including ICRC). Appeal has been expanded several times, incorporating the response in Equateur, Eastern DRC and in all neighboring Priority 1 countries (Rwanda, Burundi, S.Sudan and Uganda).Â Â
Transfer of the last FCDO top-up (Â£1m) to IFRC EVD appeal

title.narrative: Guinea Disaster Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: The Guinean Red Cross is a key player in the national system of response to emergencies in Guinea. In the response to the epidemic of Ebola, the CRG provided leadership of the Hygiene and Sanitation Commission in addition to the services usually offered to communities in responding to emergencies. Disaster Preparedness and response is one of the three pillars of its strategic development plan 2015-2020. This program aims to develop the capacities of the Guinean Red Cross at central and branches levels to better respond to emergencies across Guinea and assist more victims. Objectives are to increase their capacity to prepare for and respond to disasters, increase operational efficiency and accountability to beneficiaries and technical and financial partners, to improve information sharing and coordination both internal and external and their ability to learn from their operations. The Guinean Red Cross aims through this project, to ensure the relevance, quality, scope and sustainability of services in disaster preparedness and response. The project started at the end of 2016 and concluded in December 2018, funded with remaining Ebola appeal funds until the end of 2018. In Guinea BRC works though a consortium with the Danish RC and the Swiss RC, with BRC being the lead (full BRC funding + technical advice) on this DM initiative. A final external evaluation took place in March 2019 to assess the progress against indicators and evaluate the quality and efficiency of the programme, learn from this experience and provide recommendation to design a second phase. A 6 months extension to the phase 1 has been developed in June and July 2019. It intends to take forward some recommendations from the final evaluation report to strengthen the achievement of phase 1

title.narrative: Guinea RHR project

description.narrative: The Guinean Red Cross is a key player in the national system of response to emergencies in Guinea. In the response to the epidemic of Ebola the CRG provided leadership of the Hygiene and Sanitation Commission in addition to the services usually offered to communities in responding to emergencies. Community health is one of the three pillars of its strategic development plan 2015-2020. This project aims to increase the resilience of the communities in the region of Moyenne Guinée toward diseases with epidemic potential. The GRC are currently the best placed actor in Guinea to implement community-based health programs including community based surveillance through their network of volunteers trained in first aid disaster management and PHAST and their experience in social mobilization and management of several pillars of intervention against Ebola The project will support the development of a strong RC volunteer and health worker network to implement community-based surveillance systems The GRC approach is in line with the National Plan to strengthen epidemiological surveillance developed by the Ministry of Health in Guinea. This project is one of the components of a larger reproductive and sexual health programme implemented by the GRC and the Danish Red Cross since 2009 in Moyenne Guinée. A consortium will be formed with Danish and Swiss Red cross Danish Red Cross being the lead agency.

title.narrative: Guinea 2021 Ebola Outbreak

description.narrative: On the 14th of February 2021, health authorities in Guinea declared an Ebola outbreak in the rural community of GouÃ©kÃ© in Nâ€™Zerekore prefecture. Due to the location of the outbreak, there is a high risk of the outbreak spreading to neighbouring countries.Â IFRC has launched a multi-country Emergency Appeal on the 19th Feb 2021 with a total budget of CHF 8.5 million. The overall objective of the Appeal is to reduce morbidity and mortality resulting from the EVD outbreak in Guinea, and to prepare for, prevent and rapidly contain outbreaks of EVD should the virus spread to other regions of Guinea and neighbouring countries (Sierra Leone, Liberia, CÃ´te dÂ´Ivoire, Mali and Senegal).Â BRC's Ebola Appeal is open (using the same as for the DRC outbreak).Â
This is to transfer the agreed Â£100,000 contribution from BRC to the Guinea Ebola Emergency Appeal

title.narrative: Faith leaders round table against Ebola Virus Disease In Eastern DRC

description.narrative: The INRB laboratory in Butembo confirmed on February 6, 2021 the presence of the Ebola virus in a sample taken from a patient in the Masoya health area (Biena health zone). February 07, 2021, the Minister of Public Health announced the resurgence of EVD and field deployment of a team from the Provincial Ministry in charge of Health and the Provincial Health Division. To this must be added the establishment of a provincial team to coordinate response activities at the branch of the Provincial Health Division (DSP) of Butembo. Priority interventions to break the chain of transmission continue in the province of North Kivu. These include strengthening surveillance, vaccination, care and communication on risks and community engagement in affected health zones. It should be noted that although the improvement in the reporting of alerts remains encouraging, very little information on the level of preparedness of health zones at risk is available, while the mobility of populations between health zones in the territory. Lubero remains fairly fluid, particularly towards the health zones of Butembo and Kalunguta. Currently, the Province has 11 new confirmed cases in 3 health zones (Biena, Katwa and Musienene). 751 contacts were inventoried, of which 77.8% were followed up.

title.narrative: Partner reflection on Best practices

description.narrative:
Building from the past experiences especially related to challenges of community involvement, religious leaders want to be proactive as they recognize their responsibility in the response. The intention is to assess the level of their involvement and build on the recommendations from the Round Table that were organized during the 11th Ebola Epidemic.
It is in this sense that a reflection workshop will be organized in Butembo with the financial support from CAFOD in collaboration with the Anglican Church and Caritas beni-Butembo in order to revisit how best the religious leaders can act meaningfully and to best use their positions, their voices, their influence to limit the escalation of this 12th wave of Ebola that stand out as another significant threat to an area that is already fragile.

title.narrative: AHP RDC Ebola Response

description.narrative: Ebola Community Engagement and Prevention (ECEP) will expand on existing EVD response projects currently being implemented by CAN DO partners. It is informed by the national EVD emergency response strategy (SRP4) and will focus on: strengthening community engagement in 7 health zones (e.g. through training of health workers, leaders and groups); awareness raising through mass communication (e.g. including those with access to the general population); and EVD prevention through WASH activities (e.g. supply of hand washing kits in schools/churches/mosques) in 7 health zones reaching nearly 1.8M people in the target areas. The project will continue to build on a mass communication and WASH programming based on careful assessment of communities’ knowledge, practices and behaviours, that is tested and developed in cooperation with the communities.

title.narrative: Supporting the ACEAC-CENCO Bishops’ advocacy mission in Eastern DRC

description.narrative: The ACEAC’ mission, as a socio-pastoral action platform of all Catholic Churches in the Great Lakes Sub-region, crosses the borders of nations, tribes, ethnicities and languages, and according to its Statutes,). It aims to be "a forum for exploring ways and means of promoting dialogue and concertation, mutual assistance and ecclesial cooperation among affiliated Episcopal Conferences for the in-depth evangelisation of people in Africa in their cultural, social and religious environment. In Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, recurrent insecurity is a feature of this region, with inter-ethnic and cross-border rebellion conflicts. Indeed, several people have died there in savage massacres. Since 2014, there are 4000 people reported killed in the Diocese of Beni-Butembo alone. And as misfortune never comes alone, the region has been shaken by the Ebola virus epidemic which has caused more than 2000 deaths, while the Covid-19 continues to spread. As a result, the population of eastern DRCongo complains of being abandoned by the international and even national community. Indeed, Mgr Melchisédech Sikuli, Bishop of Butembo-Beni echoed this in his interview with the newspaper Forum des As on 6 November 2020. He castigated the revolting indifference towards the massacres of the population (cf. Forum des As n° 6279 of Friday, November 6, 2020, p. 8). Mgr Melchisédech Sikuli had voiced the same cry of alarm during the CENCO Plenary Assembly (October 2020). This project intends to advocate for enabling peace in eastern DRC on behalf of affected communities, to gather information on the ground to nourish advocacy action and to undertake and refresh relationship with various stakeholders.
